questions.text: Which of the following promotes gastric emptying?
questions.solution:
Gastrin is secreted by G cells in the gastric antrum and promotes gastric emptying. It has mild to moderate stimulatory effects on the motor functions of the body of the stomach and also enhances the activity of the pyloric pump.

questions.text: Mutation in which of the following genes causes Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Wilson's disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. It an autosomal recessive condition.

The ATP7B gene is located on chromosome 13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions:

  • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
  • Helps excrete free copper in bile.

The resulting ATP7B deficiency leads to reduced bound copper and impaired free copper excretion. This causes excess deposition of free copper in the tissues, particularly in the liver, brain and eye.

Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive condition leading to impaired absorption of copper and subsequent copper deficiency. Here, the mutation is in the ATP7A gene.

questions.text: Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, only dexamethasone is shown to reduce mortality in severe covid19 cases.

Patients with severe COVID-19 can develop a systemic inflammatory response that can lead to lung injury and multisystem organ dysfunction. It has been proposed that the potent anti-inflammatory effects of corticosteroids might prevent or mitigate these deleterious effects and help reduce mortality.

In severe cases, Dexamethasone is administered at doses of 6mg IV/PO once daily for 10 days or until hospital discharge. If dexamethasone is not available, then, equivalent doses of other corticosteroids, like prednisone, methylprednisone, or hydrocortisone may be used.

Other options:

  • There is no evidence that favipiravir reduces mortality. It reduces duration of hospitalisation in mild to moderate disease. 
  • In a recent update, WHO recommended against the use of remdesivir in hospitalized patients, regardless of disease severity, as there is no evidence that it improves survival.

questions.text: Which of the following patients with malaria can be treated with primaquine?

choices.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman at 30 weeks of gestation
A 10-year-old boy diagnosed with G6PD deficiency
A 40-year-old woman recently treated for a flare-up of SLE
A 60-year-old man who had a myocardial infarction 4 months ago

questions.solution:
Cardiac disease is not a contraindication for the use of primaquine. It is contraindicated in:

  • Infants
  • Pregnant and lactating women
  • Patients with G6PD deficiency
  • Patients at risk of developing granulocytopenia:
    • Systemic diseases including active RA and SLE
    • Drugs that cause hemolysis or bone marrow depression

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman after a trivial fall presents with pelvic fracture along with left femoral nerve injury. The function of all of the following muscles will be affected except:
questions.solution:
Gracilis is supplied by the obturator nerve and not the femoral nerve. Hence, the function of gracilis muscle will be normal in this patient.

Branches of the femoral nerve:

  • Before entering the thigh, the femoral nerve supplies branches to the iliacus and pectineus muscles
  • The anterior division of femoral nerves supplies the sartorius and gives sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the thigh by the branches medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh and intermediate cutaneous nerve of the thigh
  • The posterior division of the femoral nerve supplies branches to the quadriceps femoris muscles, knee joint and gives sensation to the medial aspect of the leg by the saphenous nerve.

The image given below shows the course of the femoral nerve.

questions.text: A male patient from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the lower limb. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally as shown below, and is non-pitting. The skin over the swelling is thickened. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis). The best next step would be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic (between 10 pm and 4 am) in India.

Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi.

Elephantiasis is a delayed sequel to repeated lymphangitis, obstruction and lymphedema. Repeated leakage of lymph into tissues first results in lymphedema, then to elephantiasis.

Treatment: 

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about secretory vesicle transport?
questions.solution:
Vesicular transport has no relation to the concentration gradient.

Vesicular transport requires energy expenditure by the cell, so this is an active method of membrane transport. Energy is needed to accomplish vesicle formation and vesicle movement within the cell.

 

METHOD OF TRANSPORT SUBSTANCE INVOLVED ENERGY REQUIREMENT
Endocytosis

Uptake of fluids or macromolecules by the cell

  

    1. Pinocytosis

Substances ingested are in solution

Small molecules are taken up by invaginations of the plasma membrane and pinch off to form a vesicle.

    2. Phagocytosis

 Multimolecular particles (e.g: bacteria, cellular debris) Active. The cell extends pseudopods around the particle to form a vesicle.
    3. Receptor-mediated Specific large polar molecule (e.g: Transferrin, LDL) Active. Molecules bind to receptors that are localized in clathrin coated pits in the plasma membrane, endocytosed in vesicles that fuse with lysosomes
Transcytosis

Intact proteins across epithelial barriers (e.g: ingested antibodies in maternal milk across intestinal epithelia)

Movement of endocytosed vesicles between the apical and basolateral compartments of cells.
Exocytosis Secretary products (e.g: hormones, enzymes), as well as large molecules that pass through the cell intact. Active. An increase in cytosolic Ca2+ induces fusion of a secretory vesicle with the plasma membrane; the vesicle opens up and releases its contents.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who was sexually abused is now pregnant and wants to undergo an abortion. She was diagnosed with autism at the age of 2 years. According to the MTP Act, consent for this procedure is needed from whom?
questions.solution:
According to the MTP Act, for medical termination of pregnancy, consent is needed from the woman only.

Consent of the husband is not necessary. Abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband if the woman is not willing.

Written consent of the guardian or family is required only when the woman in question is mentally ill or a minor. A diagnosis of autism wouldn't affect the decision-making capacity of the woman.

questions.text: A 1-week-old infant was born with a laryngeal defect. CT-scan revealed an ​absence of greater cornu of the hyoid and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Greater horn (greater cornu) and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone are formed from the 3rd pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is being counseled for surgery for her long-standing dacryocystitis. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) as it re-establishes the lacrimal drainage.

One of the sequelae of chronic dacryocystitis is mucocele formation, which when infected, leads to pyocele formation and finally lacrimal fibrosis. Treatment of lacrimal sac fibrosis is dacryocystectomy.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness for the past 3 months. She is diagnosed to have microcytic hypochromic anemia. The stool microscopy reveals the following. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of iron deficiency anemia and the stool microscopy showing the egg is suggestive of infection by Ancylostoma duodenale.

Eggs of both Ancylostoma duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

The hookworm eggs are oval or elliptical in shape, colorless, and non-bile stained. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. The ovum is segmented with 4 to 8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and eggshell. Eggs float in the saturated salt solution.

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin or subcutaneous tissue. The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where they may cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to the pharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. 

A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with the absorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss.

The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with Ancylostoma duodenale and 0.03 mL with Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Dysdiadochokinesia refers to which of the following?

choices.text: Inability to perform the Tandem-Gait test
Inability to stand without swaying with eyes open
Inability to perform rapid alternating movements with the hands

questions.solution:
Dysdiadochokinesia—Inability to Perform Rapid Alternating Movements.

  • In cerebellar lesions, the motor control system fails to predict where the different parts of the body will be at a given time. As a result, the succeeding movement may begin much too early or much too late and no orderly “progression of movement” can occur.
  • So, a series of stalled attempted but jumbled movements occurs instead of the normal coordinated movements. This condition is called dysdiadochokinesia.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man presents  with fever and tachycardia since last night. He is drowsy, with a BP of 92/54 mmHg and temperature of 103 °F. He was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection 5 days ago for which antibiotics were prescribed. He is a known case of colon cancer and also has a history of myocardial infarction 6 months ago. What type of shock is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of septic shock as a result of gram-negative sepsis originating from a urinary tract infection.

Gram-negative organisms contain lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane, which triggers the release of cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF). These cytokines cause a cascade of events culminating in increased capillary permeability and redistribution of circulatory volume into the interstitium. It is also known as warm shock, due to fever and increased perfusion.

Other types of shock are:

  • Anaphylactic shock - sudden circulatory collapse due to type I hypersensitivity reaction
  • Cardiogenic shock - ventricular failure, often following myocardial infarction; is a form of cold shock
  • Hypovolemic shock - due to blood or fluid loss

questions.text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and suffered a head injury. On examination, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated BP in this condition?
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for elevated BP in head injury patient is Cushing reflex.

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

questions.text: You have sent a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma and hearing loss for tympanometry. Which of the following tympanometry curves do you expect to find?
questions.solution:
Type B tympanometry curve is expected in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Due to mechanical obstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumor, serous otitis media occurs, causing conductive hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 39-year-old man who presented with burning pain in lower extremities along with staggering gait was diagnosed with burning feet syndrome. On further evaluation, he was found to be deficient in a particular vitamin. The deficient vitamin contains which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
The vitamin that is deficient in burning feet syndrome (nutritional melalgia) is vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid) which contains beta-alanine.

The burning sensation in burning feet syndrome (nutritional melalgia) typically follows a characteristic pattern with intense burning pain in both feet. It may begin in soles and spread upward can progress from feet to ankles and eventually calves. Heat sensation may persist even when feet feel physically cold. It exhibits a nocturnal pattern wherein the symptoms are significantly worse at night.

Beta-alanine is seen in:

  • Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5): As a structural component.
  • Coenzyme A: Derived from pantothenic acid, essential for fatty acid metabolism and many other biochemical reactions.
  • Carnosine: A dipeptide of beta-alanine and histidine, found in muscle tissue.
  • Anserine: A methylated form of carnosine found in skeletal muscle.
  • Acyl Carrier Protein (ACP): A component of fatty acid synthesis complex containing a pantetheine prosthetic group.

Other features of pantothenic acid deficiency are GI disturbances, Paraesthesia, Muscle cramps, Ataxia, Fatigue, Poor wound healing and Sleep disturbances.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the finding as shown below. She is diagnosed with a right-sided senile cataract. Identify the stage.
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of a Morgagnian hyper-mature cataract.

Morgagnian hyper-mature cataracts are characterized by liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile cataract:

  • Cortical (soft cataract)- 75%   
  • Nuclear (hard cataract)- 25%

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract 

 

Nuclear cataracts: These may be pigmented due to the deposition of urochrome pigments.

  • Cataracta brunescens (brown)
  • Cataracta nigra (black)
  • Cataracta rubra (red)

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.solution:
Gap junctions are made of connexons. Connexons are in turn made of units called connexins.

questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

  • Lag phase (Marked as A): Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. Cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase. This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed.
  • Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B): In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  • Stationary phase (Marked as C): Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. It's a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation occurs during this phase. 
  • Phase of decline (Marked as D): In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: Which of these is not a dopaminergic pathway?
questions.solution:
Corticostrial pathway is not a dopaminergic pathway.

The corticostrial pathway is the primary input pathway for the basal ganglia which uses glutamate as the neurotransmitter.

Important dopaminergic pathways are:

  • Mesolimbic pathway - Increased activity responsible for positive symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Mesocortical pathway - Decreased activity responsible for negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Nigrostriatal pathway - Decreased activity causes extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • Tuberoinfundibular pathway - Decreased activity causes increase in prolactin.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with growth retardation, recurrent attacks of hypoglycemia, doll-like facies with thin extremities and massive hepatomegaly. Blood examination reveals increased lactic acid, triglyceride, and uric acid levels. All of the following complications can be expected in this child except:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this clinical scenario is von Gierke’s disease. Cardiomyopathy is not a complication of von Gierke’s disease. On the contrary, cardiomyopathy is associated with Pompe's disease.

Enzyme deficient in von Gierke’s disease is glucose-6-phosphatase (common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis). Inheritance is autosomal recessive. 

Glycogen accumulation occurs in the liver and renal tubular cells. Clinical features include:

  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Ketosis
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperuricemia

A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

Complications of von Gierke's disease:

  • Polycystic ovaries
  • Osteopenia
  • Hepatic adenoma
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Pancreatitis.
  • Renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of the DNA polymerase complex?
questions.solution:
A number of different DNA polymerase molecules engage in DNA replication that share three important properties: Chain elongation, processivity, and proofreading.

Unwinding of DNA is done by enzyme helicase.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following skin lesions. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques in an HIV-positive patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8. It also causes primary effusion lymphoma. 

HHV-8 or Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is known to cause Kaposi’s sarcoma, especially in immunocompromised persons. Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, AIDS patients, and organ transplant recipients are all at a high risk of showing signs of infection.

It is one of the currently known human cancer viruses or oncoviruses.

KSHV is a known causative agent of four diseases:

  1. Kaposi's sarcoma
  2. KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD)
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tributary of cavernous sinus?
questions.solution:
The deep middle cerebral vein is not a tributary of the cavernous sinus. It joins the anterior cerebral and striate veins to form the basal vein. 

The superficial middle cerebral vein drains into the cavernous sinus.

The tributaries of cavernous sinus are

  • From orbit: Superior and inferior ophthalmic veins
  • From cranium: Sphenoparietal sinus, superficial middle cerebral vein, and inferior cerebral vein.

The cavernous sinus drains into

  • Transverse sinus via superior petrosal sinus
  • Internal jugular vein via inferior petrosal sinus
  • Pterygoid plexus of veins via emissary veins
  • Superior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: A 15 months old child is brought to the OPD because of developmental delay and clouded appearance of cornea in both eyes. The other examination findings of the child are shown in the image below. The elder sibling of the child also has similar findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows coarse facial features, umbilical hernia, claw hand, and thoracolumbar gibbus. These features along with corneal opacity are highly suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses.

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are a group of genetic disorders affecting the glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). The given features are suggestive of MPS type 1.

The given image shows cloudy cornea in mucopolysaccharidosis:

Other options:

Von Gierke’s disease/ Glycogen storage disease type 1a- Occurs due to the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. It presents with hepatosplenomegaly and fasting hypoglycemia.

Down's syndrome- Occurs due to trisomy 21. It presents with developmental delay and a flattened facial profile but it does not show features like clouded cornea and gibbus.

Refsum disease- It is a disorder of fatty acid metabolism. It occurs due to deficiency of alpha-hydroxylase causing phytanic acid accumulation in the tissues. It presents with neurological symptoms, cerebellar ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, and polyneuropathy.

questions.text: Shortest and narrowest segment of facial nerve is ______
questions.solution:
Shortest and narrowest segment of facial nerve is labyrinthine segment.

Labyrinthine segment: From fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus oedema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis. This is also the shortest segment of the nerve.

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called?
questions.solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia.

Metaplasia is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

Examples of metaplasia include:

  • Columnar to squamous epithelium (also called squamous metaplasia):
    • This is the most common type of metaplasia, and is usually seen in the respiratory tract in cases of chronic smoking or sometimes in vitamin A deficiency,
    • It may also be present in cases where there are stones in the excretory ducts of salivary glands, pancreas, or bile ducts, where, the normal secretory columnar epithelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Squamous to columnar epithelium (also called columnar metaplasia): It is seen in Barrett's oesophagus.
  • Connective tissue metaplasia: It refers to the formation of bone, cartilage, or adipose tissue in the tissues where they are normally absent. One such example is myositis ossificans, a condition where there is the formation of bone within the muscle.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism.
questions.solution:
The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain. 

Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.

Actinomyces and Corynebacterium are non-acid-fast.

The image below shows Nocardia stained using an acid fast staining technique.

 

The image given below is of a Gram stained specimen of Actinomyces israelii. 

 

The images below show the staining characteristics of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with the history of polyuria and polydipsia was diagnosed to be suffering from type 1 DM. What will be the effect of this condition on the free fatty acid(FFA) level in this boy?

choices.text: Decreased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to Low glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Decreased FFA level due to low glucagon: insulin ratio

questions.solution:
In type I diabetes mellitus, there is an Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state and hence glucagon: insulin ratio will be high. The level of FFA, in turn, is controlled by glucagon:insulin ratio. Glucagon increases the FFA level and insulin has the opposite effect.

Note: Low insulin state also causes increased fatty acid oxidation leading to increased ketone body production and ketosis.

questions.text: Oil red O stain is used in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Oil red O (ORO) stain is used in frozen section.

Oil red O stains lipid/ fats and gives a characteristic orange/red appearance. It is used in the unfixed frozen sections as the fixation of fats with other routine processes may lose the lipid content. 10% Neutral buffer formaldehyde (NBF) is the preferred fixative in histopathological sections staining with Oil red O. Zenker's fixative and Helly's fixative are best avoided during staining with ORO.

Oil red O stains the lipid in the vacuoles in the pulmonary vasculature. It can be useful in identifying fat emboli in lung tissue, diagnosing renal cell carcinoma, and sebaceous gland tumors of the skin.

 Other stains used for lipids or fats:

  • Nile blue sulfate The preferred fixative is formal calcium.
  • Osmic acid is used in the frozen section. 10% NBF is the preferred fixative
  • Sudan black B is used in the frozen section. The preferred fixative is 10% NBF.

Other Options:

Option A: Formalin fixation- Formalin as 10% neutral buffered formalin (NBF) is the most common fixative used in diagnostic pathology.

Option C: Ethyl alcohol- Ideal fixative for cytological smears because it acts quickly and gives good nuclear detail.

Option D: Glutaraldehyde- Preferred fixative in electron microscopy. The standard solution is a 2.5% buffered glutaraldehyde.

The image below shows microscopy of an oil-red O-stained bronchoalveolar lavage sample from a patient with acute lung injury.

The image shows the lipid vesicles in the adipocytes stained using oil-red-O staining.

questions.text: While performing tympanoplasty, the ENT surgeon notices that the floor of the middle ear is deficient. Which of the following structures is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
The internal jugular vein is susceptible to injury in this given clinical scenario.

The floor of the middle ear is related to the internal jugular vein. Occasionally, the floor is deficient and the jugular bulb is then covered only by fibrous tissue and a mucous membrane making it susceptible to injury during middle ear surgery.

The middle ear can be likened to a room with a roof, floor, and 4 walls (anterior, posterior, medial & lateral), as shown in the image:

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is _______.
questions.solution:
• Chevallet fracture - Fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.
  • Jarjaway fracture – Fracture line starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backward just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation to confirm acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma.

It is superior to a CT scan. Intracanalicular tumors measuring even a few millimeters can be easily diagnosed by this method.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant?
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder.

It is caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene.

The primary defect is abnormal chondrocyte proliferation at the growth plate that causes development of short and thick bones.

Clinical features:

  • Short limbs
  • Normal trunk
  • Large head
  • Saddle nose
  • Exaggerated lumbar lordosis
  • Severe spinal deformity may lead to cord compression

questions.text: Identify the culture medium shown in the given image_________
questions.solution:
Loeffler's serum slope is an Enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Advantage of Loeffler's serum slope

  • Rapid growth(6-8 hrs)
  • Best medium for metachromatic granules production

Disadvantage: As it is not a selective medium, if incubated beyond 6-8 hrs, it supports the growth of commensals also.

Other options:

Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the image below. It is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae because the antimicrobials present in it, suppress the growth of other commensal organisms which may inhibit the growth of N.gonorrhoeae. Thayer Martin Medium selectively favors the growth of Neisseria by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with Vancomycin, gram-negative organisms (except Neisseria) with Trimethoprim and Colistin, and fungi with Nystatin

Thayer-Martin medium contains antimicrobials like vancomycin 3.0 mg, colistin 7.5 mg, and nystatin 12.5 units per ml of agar, in chocolate agar.

Lowenstein-Jenson medium is shown in the image below. It is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture.The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Components of LJ medium:

  • Egg: Provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism.
  • Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants.
  • Mineral salt solution: Buffer.
  • Glycerol: Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis.
  • L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen. 

Colony characteristics on LJ Medium:

Mycobacterium bovis forms moist, smooth, flat, white colonies on LJ media that break-up easily when touched. 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies with a wrinkled surface, tenacious, difficult to emulsify, creamy white and buff-colored. (Rough, tough, buff). 

 Middle Brook’s media:

  • Liquid Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Used for preparation of antigens and vaccines, and sensitivity testing.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting bacterial RNA polymerase?
questions.solution:
Rifampin acts by inhibiting bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase.

Rifampin enters M. tuberculosis bacilli in a concentration-dependent manner, achieving steady-state concentrations within 15 minutes. Rifampin binds to the β subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (rpoB) to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. Drug binding suppresses chain formation in RNA synthesis.

Other options:

  • Aminoglycosides: The primary intracellular site of action of the aminoglycosides is the 30S ribosomal subunit. Aminoglycosides interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis, leading to the accumulation of abnormal initiation complexes; the drugs also can cause misreading of the mRNA template and incorporation of incorrect amino acids into the growing polypeptide chains.
  • Macrolides: Macrolide and ketolide antibiotics are bacteriostatic agents that inhibit protein synthesis by binding reversibly to 50S ribosomal subunits of sensitive microorganisms.
  • Cephalosporins: Bactericidal agents which act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text:
The section which lays down the punishment for the offence of rape is:

BNS-Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita
questions.solution:
Section 64 BNS (376 IPC) lays down the punishment for the offence of rape. 

Section 64 (1) of the BNS(Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita) outlines the punishment for rape and section 64 (2) outlines the punishment for rape in custody/rape by a person in a position of authority or trust.

Other options :

Option A : Section 63 BNS (375 IPC) defines rape.

Option C : Section 70 BNS (376D IPC) defines gang rape and lays down the punishment for the same. The people who commit this act shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than twenty years, which may extend to imprisonment for life, and with a fine.

Option D : Section 74 BNS (354 IPC) deals with assault or use of criminal force on a woman with the intent to outrage her modesty.

questions.text: A young male presents with clear watery fluid coming from the nose following RTA. Patient is otherwise stable. Management of choice is________
questions.solution:
• Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea can be managed by conservative measures such as
    • Bed rest
    • Elevating the head of the bed
    • Stool softeners
    • Avoidance of nose blowing, sneezing and straining.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics can be used to prevent meningitis.
  • Surgery is done if conservative management fails.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cardiac muscle?
questions.solution:
Cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized due to long refractory period.

In cardiac myocytes, depolarization proceeds rapidly and an overshoot of the zero potential is present. This is followed by a plateau before the membrane potential reaches the RMP (-90mV). This plateau phase lasts for 200 msec or more. Repolarization is therefore not complete until contraction is 50% completed.

Phases of cardiac action potential

  • 0→ Depolarisation and overshoot
    • Due to opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels
  • 1→ Initial rapid repolarization
    • Due to closure of Na+ channels and opening up of K+ channels
  • 2→ Plateau phase
    • Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
  • 3→ late rapid repolarization
  • 4→ Baseline (RMP)
    • Phases 3 and 4 are due closure of Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux through K+ channels.
  • During phases 0 to 2 and about half of phase 3 of cardiac action potential, cardiac muscle cannot be excited again, that is, it is in its absolute refractory period. It remains relatively refractory until phase 4. Thus, cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized.

questions.text: What is the finding in the given EEG of an infant?
questions.solution:
Hypsarrhythmia is an abnormal interictal pattern which consists of diffuse, giant slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves. During the clinical spasm, there is a marked suppression of the EEG background (the electrodecremental response).

Hypsarrhythmias are usually seen in epileptic spasms. These are characterized by a briefly sustained flexion or extension of predominantly proximal muscles, including truncal muscles.

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of thyroglossal cyst develops a neck swelling. The biopsy of the lesion is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows psammoma bodies, which are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. This type of carcinoma is associated with a history of long-standing unresected thyroglossal cyst.

Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures often present within the cores of papillae in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. These structures are almost never found in follicular and medullary carcinomas. They arise from:

  • Infarction and dystrophic calcification of papillae tips
  • Calcification of intra-lymphatic tumor thrombi.

Psammoma bodies are seen in:

  • Papillary carcinoma (thyroid, kidney, endometrium, lungs)
  • Prolactinoma
  • Meningioma
  • Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was diagnosed with a submandibular gland tumour and posted for surgical removal of the gland along with its duct. Following surgery, he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the taste sensations are present. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
General sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by lingual nerve, which is likely to be inujured in this case.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue,

  • General sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.
  • Taste sensation is carried by chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue,

  • Both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngealnerve.

Valleculae is supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a fever and weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. A bone marrow biopsy is obtained later and is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 

ALL is more common in childhood. Clinical features of ALL include:

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) color changes shown?
questions.solution:
From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.

Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color and thus cannot be used. Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square compared to the outer circle.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: Fracture through the line shown in the image is called as?
questions.solution:
The fracture shown in the given image is a hinge fracture of the base of the skull. This is also called as a motorcyclist's fracture.

It is a basal linear fracture that passes across the floor of the middle cranial fossa, often following the petrous temporal or greater wing of the sphenoid bone into the pituitary fossa. This frequently continues symmetrically across the other middle fossa separating the base of the skull into two halves, usually being caused by a heavy blow on the side of the head.

Other options:

Option A: A ring fracture is a fracture in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum. If the kinetic energy of the fall is not absorbed by fractures of the legs, pelvis, or spine, the impact is transmitted up the cervical spine. This force may be rammed into the skull, carrying a circle of occipital bone with it.

The image given below shows the fracture line of a ring fracture.

Option C: Battle's fracture is an outdated term for a fracture of the base of the skull, typically associated with a head injury. It is often identified by Battle's sign, a bruise behind the ear indicating possible basilar skull fracture.

Option D: Plumber's fracture refers to a stress fracture of the ribs, often caused by repetitive activities involving twisting or lifting. It is commonly seen in occupations requiring strenuous upper body movements, such as plumbing.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: The following graph displays which physiological law of the heart?
questions.solution:
The diagram displays the Length-Tension relationship for a cardiac muscle explaining the Starling law of the heart.

In the body, the initial length of the fibers is determined by the degree of diastolic filling of the heart, and the pressure developed in the ventricle is proportional to the volume of the ventricle at the end of the filling phase (Starling law of the heart).

  • The developed tension increases as the diastolic volume increases until it reaches a maximum, then tends to decrease.
  • The decrease is due to beginning disruption of the myocardial fibers and not due to a decrease in the number of cross-bridges between actin and myosin as seen in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: Cardiotoxicity is a unique adverse effect of ________
questions.solution:
Cardiotoxicity is a unique adverse effect of doxorubicin. It is an anthracycline group of anticancer antibiotics.

Doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy takes two forms:

  • Acute: pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome, arrhythmias, ST and T wave changes in ECG.
  • Chronic: dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is best described by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts smothering. It refers to the blockage of the external air passages, usually by a hand or soft fabric.

  • Burking: a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing the chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands.
  • Throttling/manual strangulation: defined as compression and strangulation with bare hands.
     
  • Choking: blockage of the upper airways by some foreign body, but is also used for manual strangulation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma.

The biopsy specimen in schwannoma shows hypocellular (Antoni B) and hypercellular areas (Antoni A). Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.

The histological section of a schwannoma showing Antoni A, Antoni B and Verocay bodies is given below:

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves. Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, the right heart valves may be involved.

Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows a pale waxy disc, attenuated arteries, and bony spicules, which implies retinitis pigmentosa (RP).  

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common, and among the hereditary type, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry: Initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

There is no effective treatment for RP.

questions.text: Which of the following was launched to ensure complete immunization of children?
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It has been now modified to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, which targets the same goal by December 2018. 

It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month). The diseases include:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The ones included recently are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. On examination, a pseudomembrane was noted in the oral cavity along with the neck finding as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true regarding the membrane observed?

choices.text: Firmly adherent and bleeds on removal

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and bull-neck appearance (image) point to the diagnosis of diphtheria. The diphtheritic membrane is firmly adherent and bleeds on removal.

A greyish-white membrane forms over the tonsils in the oropharynx and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey. It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. In the larynx, the diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction.

Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a bull-neck appearance. The patient is ill and toxaemic, but fever seldom rises above 38°C.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for:
questions.solution:
Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the posteroinferior or anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: The life cycle of which of the following is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus.

Salient points on Nipah virus disease:

  • It is an RNA virus which belongs to family Paramyxoviridae, genus henipavirus.
  • It is a zoonotic virus.
  • Natural host: Fruit bats of the Pteropodidae family
  • Transmission:
    • Animals (bats, pigs) to humans
    • Human-to-human
  • Clinical features: Asymptomatic infection (subclinical), acute respiratory infection, fatal encephalitis.
  • There is no treatment or vaccine available for either people or animals. The primary treatment for humans is supportive care.
  • Nipah virus is on the WHO list of Blueprint priority diseases.

questions.text: In the given image, the artery of epistaxis is indicated by _____.
questions.solution:
Structure marked C is sphenopalatine artery which is called the “artery of epistaxis”.

It is called artery of epistaxis since the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is by the sphenopalatine artery and it is the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

  • A: Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • B: Posterior ethmoidal artery
  • D: Greater palatine artery

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anterior intercostal artery?

choices.text: Present in the 1st to 12th intercostal space
Each intercostal space has 2 anterior intercostal arteries

questions.solution:
Each intercostal space has 2 intercostal arteries.

Each of the upper 9 intercostal spaces has 2 anterior intercostal arteries and 1 posterior intercostal artery.

The 10th and 11th intercostal spaces have 1 posterior intercostal artery but no anterior intercostal artery.

Anterior intercostal arteries for the: 

  • Upper six spaces - Arise from the internal thoracic artery.
  • 7th to 9th spaces - Branches of the musculophrenic artery.

Each intercostal space has two anterior intercostal arteries: one superior and one inferior. The superior anterior intercostal artery arises from the internal thoracic artery (a branch of the subclavian artery), while the inferior anterior intercostal artery arises from the musculophrenic artery (a branch of the internal thoracic artery). These arteries run along the inferior borders of the corresponding ribs and provide blood supply to the anterior intercostal muscles and other structures in the intercostal space.

Other options:

A) The statement "Present in the 1st to 12th intercostal space" is incorrect because there are only 11 intercostal spaces in total (numbered 1 to 11) between the ribs.

C) The statement "Branch of the external thoracic artery" is incorrect. The anterior intercostal arteries are not branches of the external thoracic artery. Instead, they arise from the internal thoracic artery.

D) The statement "Branch of the aorta" is also incorrect. While the posterior intercostal arteries (which run in the costal groove on the undersurface of the ribs) arise from the thoracic aorta, the anterior intercostal arteries arise from the internal thoracic artery.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells.

Plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: The first-order neurons in the optic pathway are _____.
questions.solution:
Photoreceptors are the first-order neurons in the visual pathway.

Related Pearl: Order of neurons in the visual pathway

Order of neurons in the visual pathway

First-order neurons

Photoreceptors (rods and cones)

Second-order neurons

Bipolar cells

Third-order neurons

questions.text: A 23-year-old female diagnosed with hepatitis A complained of persistent nausea. An antiemetic was given intravenously three times a day. After two days, the patient felt painful arching of neck and upwards rolling of eyes. The antiemetic is most likely to be
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario depicted is suggestive of dystonia, which is an adverse effect observed due to D2 receptor antagonism of metoclopramide. 

Metoclopramide is an antiemetic agent which mainly acts by D2 receptor antagonism, 5HT4 receptor agonism and 5HT3 receptor antagonism. It can be used both as a prokinetic agent and antiemetic.

Other options:

  • Ondansetron and Granisetron mainly act by 5HT3 antagonism. This class of drugs are most effective in treating chemotherapy induced vomiting.
  • Nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid and acts by stimulating the CB1 subtype of cannabinoid receptors. It can lead to marijuana-like highs with euphoria, somnolence, detachment, dizziness, anxiety, nervousness, panic attack, etc. It is used to prevent chemotherapy induced vomiting when other antiemetics have failed.

questions.text: Where are owl's eye inclusion bodies seen?
questions.solution:
Owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

Cytomegalovirus is a type of herpes virus, which causes severe disease in immunocompromised patients. In most other cases, it is inapparent and marked by prolonged latency with intermittent reactivation.

Diagnosis:

  • IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). 
  • Avidity level measured by avidity index is used to describe the percentage of IgG bound to the antigen after being treated with denaturing agents.These assays are based on the fact that low avidity IgG antibodies are present during the first few months after the infection and avidity increases over time indicating maturation of the immune response. So the presence of high avidity IgG denotes a past infection rather than a primary one. Low avidity IgG signals a primary infection within the last 3-4 months. 
  • IgM detection can be used as an indicator of acute infection, but it lacks specificity for primary infection. This is because it persists for years in some individuals and is also produced during reactivation.

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true for the given distribution of ages of patients who are visiting a family planning clinic in a day?

Age in years: 20, 31, 31, 31, 25, 28, 35, 38, 31.
questions.solution:
The arithmetic mean from the following data is given by the sum of all the values, 270 divided by the number of values, 9 = 30.

The data can be arranged in ascending order as 20, 25, 28, 31, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38.

After arranging in order, the median is obtained by picking out the central value which is 31.

The mode is the most frequently occurring value, which is 31 here.

Related Pearl: The Mean (Arithmetic) in Biostatistics

  • The mean is also called the average or arithmetic mean.
  • It is the sum of all elements in the distribution divided by the number of all the elements in it.
  • It is usually denoted by μ in a population and by x̄ (x-bar) in a sample.
  • The formula for sample mean is given as:

where the sigma sign denotes summation and n is the total number of elements.

  • The arithmetic mean responds to the exact value of every element in the distribution.
  • This makes it over-sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers thus making it an inappropriate measure for skewed distributions.
  • The advantage of the arithmetic mean is that if repeated samples are taken from the same populations, they will have very similar means, i.e., the measure of central tendency that best resists the influence of fluctuation between samples is the mean.
  • The mean can be calculated only on quantitative data on an interval or a ratio scale.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought with complaints of vomiting and disorientation. He had recently gone on a camping trip where he had swum in a freshwater lake. Kernig's sign is positive and the findings of CSF wet mount microscopy are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing amoeboid trophozoite form with pseudopodia is suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. It is caused by Naegleria fowleri.

It is also known as brain-eating amoeba. It occurs in 3 forms: cyst, amoeboid trophozoite, and flagellate trophozoite forms.

The infection usually follows swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. The amoebae invade the nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges. The incubation period is 2 days to 2 weeks.

Treatment is with intravenous amphotericin B.

Other options:

Options B: Acanthamoeba cause granulomatous amoebic meningoencephalitis which is a subacute condition.

Option C: A. cantonensis is the most common cause of eosinophilic meningitis in Southeast Asia. It is a nematode(roundworm).

Option D: B.mandrillaris is a free-living ameba, which is a newly identified species reported to cause GAME.

questions.text: Two particles share the same diameter. The one which will pass through the glomerular membrane has ______

choices.text: Filtration across GBM does not depend on charge

questions.solution:
For any given molecular radius, positively charged molecules are filtered much more readily than are negatively charged molecules.

This is because the sialoproteins in the glomerular capillary wall are negatively charged, and this negative charge repels the negatively charged substances in the blood.

Studies have showed that for tracer molecules presumed to be of similar size, charges which are filtered are positive charge > neutral charge > negative charge.

questions.text: An infant is born with a birth defect as shown in the image below. It is the most common teratogenic effect of:
questions.solution:
The above illustration is suggestive of an infant with spina bifida of the open type which is the most common teratogenic effect of sodium valproate. 

Option A: Phenytoin is usually associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome. 

Option B: Topiramate has shown growth defects in animal studies and hypospadias have been shown in the male fetus but the definite relationship is lacking.

Option D: Phenobarbital has teratogenic effects similar to phenytoin.

questions.text: Which organization does the image given below stand for?

choices.text: National Programme for Control of Blindness
National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment

questions.solution: The symbol stands for National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI), which was previously called the National Programme for Control of Blindness.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major initiating response for peristalsis?
questions.solution:
The major initiating response for peristalsis is local stretching of the gut.

Peristalsis is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. It occurs in all parts of the gastrointestinal tract from the esophagus to the rectum.

The stretch initiates a circular contraction behind the stimulus and an area of relaxation in front of it. The wave of contraction then moves in an oral-to-caudal direction. This propels the contents of the lumen forward at rates that vary from 2 to 25 cm/s.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male from a suburban area presented with fever and rash, involving the palms and soles. He gives a history of bite by an organism that looks like the one seen in the image below. His vitals are stable and there is no eschar formation at the site of the bite. Which of the following can be a likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hard tick and a history of characteristic rash present on palms and soles after a tick bite and no eschar is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever due to  Rickettsia rickettsii infection.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever presents with fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia as the most common symptoms during the first 3 days. Rash is evident in only 14% of patients on the first day of illness, which is present on palms and soles.

The most common serologic test for confirmation of the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline. It is administered orally at 100 mg twice daily.

Rash on palms and soles is typically described in the following 3 diseases:

  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Hand Foot and Mouth Disease.

 The image shows a hard tick that can transmit-

  • Tick typhus (Rickettsia conorii)
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Kyasanur forest disease
  • Tularemia
  • Human babesiosis(Babesia microti)
  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (Rickettsia rickettsii).

Identification of the tick alone helps rule out the other options as Rickettsia prowazekii is louse-borne, Rickettsia typhi is flea-borne and Rickettsia tsutsugamushi is mite-borne. 

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are the hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • General morphology of ticks includes an oval shaped body, four pairs of legs and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in front. Absent.
Head Situated at anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body, ventrally. Not visible from above.

Eggs Several hundred/thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period

Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Q fever(reservoir), relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion and toxaphone. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant disorder. The family pedigree confirms the mode of inheritance.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

Patients with Marfan syndrome have pleiotropic manifestations:

  • Skeletal systems - Tall and decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers
  • Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities - mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.
  • Ocular - superio-temporal lens dislocation
