questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect of Furosemide?
questions.solution:
Furosemide causes metabolic alkalosis.

The adverse effects of furosemide (loop diuretics) are

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hyponatremia and hypokalemia (Option C)
  • Hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia (Option B)
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Increased LDL-C and decreased HDL-C
  • Glucose intolerance: hyperglycemia (Option A)
  • Ototoxicity

questions.text: The ‘en masse’ removal of organs is a feature of which of the following autopsy techniques?
questions.solution:
The ‘en masse’ removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique.

It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks. 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Rokitansky technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. Larynx and trachea are pulled downward, and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Ghon technique: Like the Rokitansky method, the Ghon method also employs the bloc method of removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal organs. However, the organs are removed 'en bloc', rather than with in-situ dissection. 
  • Letulle technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: All of the following vascular changes are observed in acute inflammation except _____.
questions.solution:
Decreased hydrostatic pressure is not a feature of acute inflammation.

Vascular events in acute inflammation

  • Vasodilation: cause of erythema and stasis of blood flow.
  • Increased vascular permeability: induced by histamine, kinins, etc
  • Increased vascular permeability allows plasma proteins and leukocytes, the mediators of host defense, to enter sites of infection or tissue damage.
  • Fluid leak from blood vessels resulting in edema

questions.text: To calculate the crude death rate of a country, at what time of the year is the population assessed?
questions.solution:
The crude death rate is a mortality indicator, which uses the mid-year population as its denominator. The mid-year population is always attributed as the population on 1st July of any year.

Hence for calculating the crude death rate, the population is assessed on the 1st of July.

 

Related Pearl: Crude death rate

Crude death rate:

  • The crude death rate is the simplest measure of mortality.
  • It is the number of deaths (from all causes) per 1000 estimated mid-year population in one year, in a given place.
  • Crude death rate =  (Number of deaths per year)/(Mid-year population) x 1000
  • Disadvantage: lacks comparability for communities with populations that differ in age, sex, race, etc.
  • Currently, the crude death rate in India is 6.0.

questions.text: Which of the following mineral is absorbed by the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the absorption of iron from a duodenal enterocyte by mucosal block theory.

Iron Absorption :

Iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1. (DMT-1)

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Clinical significance - Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed.

Iron absorption in the duodenum is mainly regulated by hepcidin. It inhibits ferroportin and suppresses the release of iron from macrophages which is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

questions.text: Which of the following cells originate from Monocytes?
questions.solution:
Microglial cells are possibly derived from the circulating monocytes which migrate into the CNS during the late fetal and early postnatal life.

The cells derived from the circulating monocytes are: alveolar macrophages in the lungs, phagocytic cells in the lymph nodes, spleen and bone marrow, Kupffer cells in liver sinusoids, and microglial cells in the CNS.

Neuroglial cells found in the parenchyma of the brain and spinal cord are broadly classified as follows:

  • Macroglia cells of ectodermal origin (neuroectoderm) and include the astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and glioblasts.
  • Microglia cells of mesodermal origin.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the primary health center with a history of snakebite. The area of the bite is painful and appears red and swollen. From his description, the snake that bit him had a triangular head with a V-shaped mark as shown in the image below. All of the following statements regarding this snake bite are true except?

choices.text: Death is due to shock and haemorrhage
Persistent bleeding from bite site is noticed
Bleeding and clotting time are prolonged

questions.solution:
From the patient's description and the image, the snake is most likely Russell's viper. The victims of Russell's viper may become oliguric within a few hours of the bite suggesting renal ischemia.

The Russell's viper has a flat and triangular head with a V-shaped mark, white in color, with the angle of the V pointing forwards. Along the back, it has three rows of diamond-shaped spots. Other points of identification include broad plates on its belly, the small scales on the head, and a shield beneath the tail divided into two rows. It is commonly found throughout India.

Russell's viper venom contains two proteases that activate the blood-clotting cascade. Though more than half the victims have minimal or no poisoning, few develop serious generalized poisoning. At the spot where venom is injected, the patient develops severe pain and the area around the bite becomes red and painful. Persistent bleeding from the bite site is a constant feature. Blisters begin to appear in some hours which progressively involves the entire limb. Skin temperature is raised. Intravascular hemolysis may lead to hemoglobinuria which progresses to renal failure.

Since the venom affects the blood-clotting cascade, the bleeding and clotting time are usually prolonged. Patients may develop hemorrhagic syndrome due to bleeding from various sites like gums, rectum, etc. Death is usually due to hemorrhagic shock.

questions.text: Methyldopa is primarily used for:
questions.solution:
Methyldopa is preferred for chronic hypertension in pregnancy based on its safety and efficacy data for both mother and fetus.

Antihypertensives found safe in pregnancy:

  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs: should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardioselective beta-blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity

Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARB)
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside 

For a hypertensive emergency in pregnancy, labetalol is considered as the first-line agent.

questions.text: The anterior segment of the eye includes all except ______.
questions.solution:
Vitreous humor is a constituent of the posterior segment of the eye.

The eyeball is divided into 2 segments:

Anterior segment

Anterior to the lens (including lens)

  • Cornea
  • Iris
  • Lens
  • Two aqueous humor-filled chambers
    • Anterior chamber
    • Posterior chamber

Posterior segment

Posterior to the lens

  • Vitreous humor
  • Retina
  • Choroid
  • Optic disc

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, supported with the image, is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis:

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring

Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment:

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

World Glaucoma Week is celebrated annually on March 7-13 to raise awareness among people on Glaucoma. The 2021 theme reflects the hope that with regular testing, people continue to see the world around us: full of beauty, charm, and adventure. The world is bright, save your sight!

questions.text: Locking of knee is:

choices.text: Lateral rotation of the femur on tibia during extension
Medial rotation of the femur on tibia during flexion
Lateral rotation of the femur on tibia during flexion
Medial rotation of the femur on tibia during extension

questions.solution:
Locking of knee is medial rotation of femur on tibia during the later stages of extension.

  • Locking of the knee joint: When standing, the knee joint is locked into position to reduce the amount of muscle work needed to maintain the standing position. The muscle responsible for locking is vastus medialis.
  • Unlocking of the knee joint: It is the lateral rotation of femur on tibia during the beginning of flexion. This is brought by the action of popliteus muscle.

questions.text: Regarding the plant shown in the image, the toxic principle is derived from which of the following?
questions.solution: The plant shown in the image is that of Papaver somniferum. The toxic part of the plant is the unripe fruit capsule and the toxic principle is derived from it.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with dysphagia and regurgitation. Radiographic examination revealed Zenker's diverticulum. Weakness located in which of the following muscles predisposes to the given condition​?
questions.solution:
Zenker's diverticulum originates through the Killian's dehiscence, which is present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus made of oblique fibres and the lower cricopharyngeus made of transverse fibres. Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called as the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

This is the site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall and therefore is the potential site for the development of the diverticula (Zenker's diverticula).

Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the circular muscle of the oesophagus.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with AIDS is initiated on antiretroviral therapy with zidovudine. Which of the following side effects is he most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely to develop anemia since it is the most common side effect of zidovudine.

Higher dosages of zidovudine lead to bone marrow suppression resulting in anemia and granulocytopenia.

Peripheral neuropathy, hepatotoxicity, and lactic acidosis are rare side effects of zidovudine.

questions.text: You observe a normal-looking tympanic membrane on otoscopy. What is its colour?
questions.solution: The normal tympanic membrane is pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent.

questions.text: All of the following statements about inverted papilloma are true except

choices.text: Arises from the lateral wall of nose
Presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis

questions.solution:
Inverted papilloma is more common in males.

Related Pearl: Inverted Papilloma

  • Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma
  • It is the most common benign tumor of the nasal cavity
  • It is a premalignant condition with 10-15% chances of turning malignant
  • Etiology: Human papilloma virus has been implicated in its etiology
  • Origin: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose from the non-olfactory epithelium of nose
  • Clinical features:
    • More common in males
    • The age group most commonly affected is 40-70 years
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis are the main presenting symptoms
    • It is a locally invasive tumor and can invade orbit and paranasal sinuses.
    • Proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation can result from orbital invasion
  • Findings:
    • It is seen as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp
  • Investigations: A biopsy is needed for diagnosis
  • Treatment: Medial maxillectomy via lateral rhinotomy or midfacial degloving approach
  • Radiotherapy can lead to malignancy

questions.text: A newborn baby is found to have deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following findings would you not expect in him?

choices.text: Loss of abduction of the arm
Loss of lateral rotation of the arm
Loss of sensation in the lateral 2 fingers
Loss of flexion of the elbow

questions.solution:
The image shows Erb's palsy (waiter's tip deformity). In this condition, there is a loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid, and not in the lateral 2 fingers.

It is caused by injury to C5, C6, and rarely C7. It is seen most commonly in babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery.

The following are seen in Erb's palsy:

  • Loss of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Loss of flexion of the elbow
  • Loss of supination of the forearm
  • Loss of biceps, supinator, and inverse supinator jerks
  • Loss of sensation over a small area of the lower part of the deltoid

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Features Erb's palsy Klumpke's Palsy
Causes

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

Hyperabduction of shoulder. Lower plexus root involved.

Eg. Difficult breech delivery, Holding on to something (e.g. a branch) during a fall, Cervical rib syndrome, Scalene syndrome
Nerves roots  C5 and C6 C8 and T1
Muscles involved

Deltoid, Supraspinatus - loss of abduction 

Infraspinatus - loss of lateral rotation 

Biceps brachii - loss of flexion and supination 

 All intrinsic muscles of the hand
Position of the upper limb/hand Policeman's tip/Waiter's tip/ Porter's tip position Claw hand
Sensory loss +/- Along the outer aspect of the arm Along the medial border of forearm and hand
ANS signs  Absent

Horner syndrome

questions.text: A child, upon ingestion of shellfish, developed a tingling sensation in the mouth, swelling of the face, lips, and tongue, and also complained of abdominal pain and dizziness. What type of reaction is this?
questions.solution:
This is an example of an anaphylactic reaction after ingestion of an allergen(shellfish). It is an IgE mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction. 

The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mild rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Prototypical Disorders

Immediate (type I) hypersensitivity

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Anaphylaxis; allergies; bronchial asthma,Atopic dermatitis

Antibody-mediated (type II)hypersensitivity

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia; Goodpasture syndrome

Immune complex-mediated (type III) hypersensitivity

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Systemic lupus erythematosus; serum sickness; Arthus reaction

Cell-mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity

Activated T lymphocytes →

(1) the release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation;

(2) T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Contact dermatitis; multiple sclerosis; type 1 diabetes; tuberculosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Iris epithelium is not derived from surface ectoderm. It is derived from neural ectoderm.

Lens, corneal epithelium, and conjunctival epithelium are all derivatives of surface ectoderm.

questions.text: A tribal farmer presented with a three-day history of right eye redness with pain. He had spent the prior week trekking up a mountain in order to travel to the nearby town and takes such trips frequently. The following lesion was observed  on examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of right eye redness with pain, and findings of a raised whitish-yellowish lesion surrounded by mild erythema, points toward a likely diagnosis of pinguecula. A history of trekking, along with chronic sunlight exposure as a farmer, acts as a risk factor because it increases the exposure to the stronger UV radiation in the mountains.

Pinguecula has a fatty appearance and is usually bilateral. They are more often located nasally than temporally. It has horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area. They are associated with a 2- to 3-fold increased incidence of age-related macular degeneration. It is seen in most eyes by 70 years of age and in almost all by 80 years of age.

Pingueculitis responds to a brief course of NSAIDs or topical corticosteroids. Simple excision may be warranted in rare cases, wherein pingueculae may be chronically inflamed or cosmetically unsatisfactory.

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management, used pacemakers should be disposed of in which of the following colored bag?

According to biomedical waste management, used pacemakers should be disposed of in a blue colored bag. All the metallic body implants and glasswares are discarded in a blue colored bag.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding anaerobic glycolysis?

choices.text: Occurs in places like the eye lens, RBC’s etc.

questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase enzyme is needed in anaerobic glycolysis.

Anaerobic glycolysis:

  • Under anaerobic conditions, pyruvate is reduced to lactate. This reaction is catalyzed by lactate dehydrogenase.
  • Since RBC’s lack mitochondria, the further reactions of pyruvate in the TCA cycle cannot take place. Hence, glycolysis in erythrocytes always ends in the formation of lactate. Also, anaerobic glycolysis is the major fate for pyruvate in the lens and cornea of the eye, kidney medulla, leukocytes, because these are all poorly vascularized structures.
  • Net ATP produced per molecule of glucose under anaerobic conditions is 2.

Related Pearl: Pyruvate metabolism

  Enzyme involved

Fate of pyruvate
1 Cahill cycle (Alanine aminotransferase)

Carries amino group from muscle to liver.

Converts alanine to pyruvate and vise-versa.
2 Pyruvate carboxylase Formation of oxaloacetate from pyruvate to be used in the TCA cycle
3 Pyruvate dehydrogenase Pyruvate to acetyl Co-A to be used in the TCA cycle
4 Lactic acid dehydrogenase Pyruvate to lactate(Anaerobic glycolysis)

questions.text: What is the source of morning blood glucose in a person fasting overnight for 12 hours ?
questions.solution:
The source of blood glucose in a person fasting overnight for 11 hours (8 pm to 7 am) is liver glycogenolysis.

First stage of fasting:

The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting i.e; 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 11 hours will be liver glycogenolysis.

Second stage of fasting:

Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days.

Substrates for gluconeogenesis are:

  • Glucogenic amino acids ( mainly alanine) from the muscle and
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue 

During fasting, the glucogenic amino acids are transported to the liver, transaminated into pyruvate, and converted to glucose.

Third stage of fasting:

  • Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by increased glucagon:insulin ratio.
  • Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. Triacylglycerols will be hydrolyzed to fatty acids and glycerol. 
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place which provides acetyl CoA. 
  • In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs. 

Final stage of fasting:

After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin. Hence glucagon:insulin ratio is increased.

Effects of increased glucagon:insulin ratio on enzymes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis:

Metabolic process         Fasting state      Fed state
Glucagon: insulin   Increased              Decreased
Gluconeogenesis    Increased                Decreased            
Glycogenolysis  Increased                Decreased
Ketogenesis  Increased                Decreased
Glycogen storage  Decreased  Increased             

Other options:

Option C: Muscle glycogen cannot contribute directly to plasma glucose, since muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase. So glycogen cannot be converted to glucose to be used as fuel during starvation. 

Option D: In the well-fed state/ absorptive state of two to four hours after a meal, dietary glucose is the main source of fuel.

questions.text: "Me-too drugs" do not differ significantly in which of the following pharmacological feature as compared to the prototypical drug?
questions.solution:
Me-too drugs are chemically related to the prototype or other chemical compounds that have an identical mechanism of action. 

Various statins present in the market can be considered as "Me-too drugs".

Eg. : Atorvastatin and Rosuvastatin have a very long duration of action but the core mechanism of action remains the same: HMG CoA reductase inhibition and decrease in cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has come for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks of gestation. How many more antenatal visits does she require to fulfill the minimum requirements as per the Maternal and Child Health program?
questions.solution:
This patient requires 3 more antenatal visits in order to fulfill the minimum requirements according to the Maternal and Child Health Program (MCH).

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO is 8. Ideally, pregnant women should attend antenatal visits according to the following schedule:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the 8th month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: Spot the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts retropharyngeal abscess which can be diagnosed on Lateral X-ray of the soft tissues of neck:

  • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • Loss of cervical lordosis
  • In acute abscess, even air-fluid level can be seen.

questions.text: Circle of Willis does not get a contribution from
questions.solution:
Circle of Willis does not get a contribution from the middle cerebral artery.

The circle of Willis is located in the interpeduncular fossa at the base of the brain. It is an anastomosis between the internal carotid arteries and vertebral arteries. It allows the blood entering from either artery to be distributed to both the cerebral hemispheres.

The arteries forming the circle of Willis are:

  • Anterior communicating artery
  • Anterior cerebral arteries
  • Internal carotid arteries
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: The main cause of increased blood flow to exercising muscles is _______.

choices.text: Increased sympathetic discharge to peripheral vessels

questions.solution:
The tremendous increase in muscle blood flow that occurs during skeletal muscle activity is caused mainly by chemicals acting directly on the muscle arterioles to cause dilation.

These chemicals include:

  • Potassium ions,
  • Adenosine triphosphate (ATP),
  • Lactic acid, and
  • Carbon dioxide.

Other factors leading to increased muscle flow include

  • sympathetic nervous system activation
  • increase in arterial pressure, and
  • increase in cardiac output.

However, the effect of local metabolites is greater than these factors in increasing the muscle blood flow. Hence, the best answer is local metabolites.

questions.text: Certain bony nodules exist within the body that are found embedded in tendons or joint capsules. Which of the following is not one of them?
questions.solution:
Certain bony nodules exist in our bodies that are found embedded within tendons or joint capsules are called as sesamoid bones. The clavicle is not a sesamoid bone.

The clavicle is classified as a long bone, and it is not found within a tendon or joint capsule.

Sesamoid bones are those which have no periosteum and that ossify after birth. They are covered by synovial membranes, which get lubrication from the synovial membrane or bursa in which they are present.

The main functions of sesamoid bones include- resisting pressure, reducing friction, changing the direction of muscle pull, and improving circulation locally.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with freckles on her face and limbs as shown below is brought with unusually sensitivity to sunlight. Early changes of squamous cell carcinomas are also noted on her face. Which of the following processes is most like to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

It is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by exaggerated sunburns and pigmentary changes on exposure to UV radiations, increased risk of developing non-melanoma and melanoma skin cancers, and neurodegeneration. They are also more prone to developing smoking-induced lung cancers. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical and it can be confirmed definitively by cellular tests for defective DNA repair. 

Management includes sun avoidance and regular follow-up to assess and treat any skin cancers. There is no cure for xeroderma pigmentosum.

questions.text: Name the structure passing through the foramen marked in the image below.

choices.text: Second division of the fifth cranial nerve
Third division of the fifth cranial nerve

questions.solution:
Second (maxillary) division of the fifth cranial nerve passes through the Foramen rotundum (foramen marked in the image).

OTHER OPTIONS:

Third division (mandibular) of the fifth cranial nerve passes through the Foramen ovale along with accessory meningeal artery.

Vidian Nerve (also known as Nerve to Pterygoid Canal) passes through the Pterygoid Canal.

The image shows the sphenoid bone. It lies in the base of the skull between the frontal, temporal, and occipital bones. It consists of a central body, paired greater and lesser wings that are spread laterally from the body, and two pterygoid processes that project downwards from the junction of the body and the greater wings.

The foramen rotundum lies superolateral to the pterygoid canal, in the greater wing of the sphenoid. It transmits the maxillary nerve.

The pterygoid canal (also called, vidian canal) is a passage in the sphenoid bone, located inferomedial to the foramen rotundum. It transmits the vidian artery, vidian vein, and the vidian nerve.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of dipalmitoyl-phosphatidyl-choline(DPPC) /dipalmitoyl lecithin. It is the major pulmonary surfactant.

Clinical relevance- Test to assess fetal lung maturity is L/S ratio - lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio. A ratio of ≥ 2 is considered normal.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is an example of point mutation?
questions.solution:
• The classic example of point mutation is sickle-cell disease.
  • This is a T-to-A DNA substitution, which in turn results in an A-to-U change in the mRNA corresponding to the sixth codon of the β-globin gene (Glutamic acid being replaced by valine).
  • Defective production of β-globin results in a variety of diseases and is due to many different lesions in and around the β-globin gene.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. These are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations
  2. Non-sense mutations

1. Missense mutations: These mutations may involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases and lead to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product.                                                                                                                                                      Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:

a) Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change.

b) Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one. An example of this type of mutation is sickle-cell anemia.

2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, β0 thalassemia.

Other options:

Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

questions.text:
A patient presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. He was started on lovastatin. What is the likely diagnosis?

LDL - Low density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).

Familial hypercholesterolemia  (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over Achilles tendon and the dorsum of hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL > 190 mg/dl, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

The image below shows Achilles tendon xanthoma and a plain lateral radiograph of both ankles showing bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum respectively.

 

 

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk for atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

 

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk for coronary disease.

Option D: Familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome is caused due to either LPL deficiency, ApoC-II deficiency, ApoA-V deficiency, or GPIHBP1 mutation. Clinically, patients present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain due to acute pancreatitis. The retinal blood vessels may be opalescent and are called lipemia retinalis. Increased levels of triglycerides (mostly >1000 mg/dL) is seen. The risk of premature coronary heart disease is low.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. What would be the most likely pathology?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer.

Salient features of a fungal corneal ulcer:

  • It is caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter.
  • Signs are more pronounced than symptoms.
  • The corneal ulcer appears dry.
  • Delicate feathery finger-like extensions are present.
  • A sterile, immune ring (yellow line of demarcation) may be present
  • Multiple, small satellite lesions may be present around the ulcer.
  • Usually, a big hypopyon is present.
  • Pigmented ulcer (brownish) may be caused by some dematiaceous species of fungi.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.
  • The most common cause is Aspergillus.

Image: Fungal corneal ulcer, with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is approved for management of obesity ?
questions.solution:
Liraglutide is approved for the management of obesity. 

GLP-1 is a physiological regulator of appetite and calorie intake, and the GLP-1 receptor is present in several areas of the brain involved in appetite regulation. Liraglutide being a GLP-1 analog lowers body weight by decreasing calorie intake.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-week old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age.

Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of  severe laryngomalacia include:

  • Difficulty feeding
  • Increased effort in breathing
  • Poor weight gain 
  • Pauses in the breathing 
  • Frequent spitting up

questions.text: A guy was sitting on the balcony which was overlooking a park. He always used to sit nude on his balcony and derived sexual gratification by observing the people that look at him. This is best described as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of exhibitionism. 

It involves behaviors over a period of 6 months or more, involving the exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. The individual obtains sexual gratification from this. This is a punishable offense (Section 294 IPC) with imprisonment up to 3 months or a fine.

The important and common sexual perversions are summed in the pearl attached below. The various punishments in the legal provisions include:

questions.text: A 64-year-old female presented with blurring of vision and pain in her left eye. She had a history of redness in her left eye about 3 months back, which she passed off as normal conjunctivitis. On tonometry, the IOP is 55 mm Hg. The slit-lamp revealed rubeosis iridis in all four quadrants. The fundus picture of the patient is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing the "splashed sauce" appearance point towards the diagnosis of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

The given scenario of 100-day glaucoma refers to neovascular glaucoma occurring after central retinal vein occlusion, because it typically occurs 3 months after the occlusive event. Up to 50% of eyes develop NVG following ischaemic CRVO.

Pan-retinal photocoagulation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the OPD with hematuria. On physical examination, he has mild sensorineural hearing loss and eye defects. His renal biopsy on electron microscopy showed basket-weave appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) in electron microscopy are highly suggestive of Alport syndrome.

The GBM in Alport syndrome shows irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning), and pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa, often producing the basket-weave appearance.

Image: Basket-weave appearance in Alport syndrome

questions.text: Identify the following image.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a septic tank. It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment. Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.

There are single and double chambered septic tanks. The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household. The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m. The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m. The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover. Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.

Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface. Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time. Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank. By these processes, sewage is purified. Soap water and phenols must not be used and desludging must be done at least once a year.

 

Related Pearl: Septic Tank

  • It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment.
  • Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.
  • Design features:
    • There are single and double chambered septic tanks.
    • The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household.
    • The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.
    • The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
    • The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m.
    • The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover.
    • Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.
  • Working:
    • Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface
    • Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time
    • Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank
    • By these processes, sewage is purified
  • Operation and maintenance:
    • Soap water and phenols must not be used
    • Desludging must be done at least once a year

questions.text: The enzyme responsible for the respiratory burst in neutrophils is ______
questions.solution:
The respiratory burst oxidase (NADPH oxidase)is responsible for the respiratory burst in neutrophils.

NADPH + 2O2 → NADP+ + 2·O2− + 2H+

NADPH oxidase in the inflammatory cells (neutrophils, eosinophils, monocytes and macrophages) produces superoxide anion by reducing oxygen by a process of respiratory burst during phagocytosis.

 There are multiple sources of oxygen radicals in the body:

  • Ionizing radiation (x-rays and UV) causes lysis of water, leading to the formation of hydroxyl radicals
  • Transition metal ions (Cu+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Fe2+) can react nonenzymatically with oxygen or hydrogen peroxide to form hydroxyl radicals
  • Nitric oxide can react with superoxide to yield peroxynitrite, which decays to form hydroxyl radicals
  • NADPH oxidase in the inflammatory cells  produces superoxide

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On further examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

  • Vernal conjunctivitis is also called as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis
  • It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years.
  • It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Classical features of conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC

  • Cobblestone papillae: upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal VKC: Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

Corneal signs in VKC:

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon resembles arcus senilus; it has a cupid's bow outline

Image: Horner Trantas spots

Other options :

Option a : In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.
 

option c : In Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is associated with, white-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva.

Option d :  Xerophthalmia is associated with epithelial xerosis and bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy was brought by his parents with concern about being increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in the left eye. Further workup reveals a tumor, the eye is enucleated and the microscopic appearance shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes . Where is the responsible gene located?
questions.solution:
The histology showing Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and clinical history of white reflex point towards a diagnosis of retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is due to mutation in Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma was first cancer known to be directly associated with a genetic abnormality.

 The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

questions.text: Rinne test positive indicates
questions.solution: Rinne test is called positive when AC (air conduction) is longer or louder than BC (bone conduction).

questions.text: What is the defective DNA repair mechanism in a patient with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)?
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ). NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair.

NHEJ deficiency confers (severe) combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.
  • Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R.

Other types of SCID:

X-linked SCID

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

questions.text: Which of the following does not inhibit the action of cytochrome oxidase?
questions.solution:
Molecular oxygen is required for the functioning of cytochrome oxidase, also known as complex IV of the electron transport chain. The enzyme is blocked by carbon monoxide, cyanide, and hydrogen sulphide. Adenosine triphosphate allosterically inhibits the enzyme.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of loose stools. On history taking, he reveals to have consumed food from a restaurant 3 hours back. Which of the following is wrong about the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of an acute episode of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The toxin involved, enterotoxins, are heat stable.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hours after consuming contaminated food (other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hours is Bacillus cereus-Emetic strains).

Enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus:

  • There are 15 enterotoxins, they are superantigens
  • It is a preformed toxin that is heat stable (Most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile).
  • Site of action: This toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting centre of the brain and also stimulates the intestinal peristaltic activity.

questions.text: Which of the following, is the rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Phosphofructokinase (PFK-1) is the rate limiting enzyme in glycolysis.

Mg2+ serves as the co-factor for the enzyme. This step is the committed step of glycolysis.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with TB is started on anti-tubercular therapy. Which of the following drugs used in his regimen is bacteriostatic?
questions.solution:
Ethambutol is a bacteriostatic antitubercular drug as it prevents the growth of mycobacteria. Fast-multiplying bacteria are highly susceptible to its action.

The bactericidal antituberculosis agents (RIPS):

  • R: Rifampicin
  • I: Isoniazid
  • P: Pyrazinamide
  • S: Streptomycin

questions.text: A study conducted in a group revealed that consumption of alcohol increases the risk of esophageal cancer, but it may be actually due to cigarette smoking. This happens due to:
questions.solution:
In this scenario, cigarette smoking is related to both the outcome of esophageal cancer and consumption of alcohol. Thus, this is an example of a confounding factor.

A confounding factor is defined as one which is associated with both exposure and outcome and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In this study to determine the role of alcohol in the etiology of esophageal cancer, smoking is considered as a confounding factor because:

  • It is associated with the consumption of alcohol (exposure).
  • It is an independent risk factor for oesophageal cancer (outcome).

In these conditions, the effects of alcohol consumption can be determined only if the influence of smoking is neutralized by matching.

questions.text: A child, upon disturbing a bee hive, had several stings. After a few minutes, the child developed breathing difficulty and hypotension. What is the drug of choice for managing this child?
questions.solution:
The child has respiratory difficulty and signs of vascular collapse which is suggestive of anaphylactic shock and the drug of choice is adrenaline.

Anaphylaxis is a type I hypersensitivity.

Immediate (Type I) Hypersensitivity

  • These are also called allergic reactions or allergies.
  • They are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals
  • IgE coats mast cells by binding to Fcεg receptors; reexposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI, activation of mast cells, and release of mediators.
  • The principal mediators are histamine, proteases, and other granule contents; prostaglandins and leukotrienes; as well as cytokines.
  • The mediators are responsible for the immediate vascular and smooth muscle reactions and the late-phase reaction (inflammation).
  • The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.
  • It occurs in two phases: immediate phase and late phase.

 Image: Sequence of events in immediate hypersensitivity

Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 by intramuscular route (IM) is the drug of choice for treatment of anaphylactic shock.In case the patient develops life threatening condition, adrenaline 0.25 mg IV is given

Note:

  • As vasodilatation is the main pathological change early in anaphylaxis, this enables the subcutaneous or intramuscular absorption of adrenaline to be rapid and effective.
  • Thus, when the disease is treated early and is progressing slowly, or venous access is difficult or the patient is unmonitored, intramuscular adrenaline has advantages in terms of safety and is usually effective.
  • Later, when intravascular volume is depleted and shock occurs with a life threatening situation, or there is severe dyspnoea or airway compromise, the intravenous route is necessary to achieve optimal absorption.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes to the hospital due to frequent episodes of abdominal pain and black tarry stools. He has been using Ibuprofen from the last 20 years due to back pain. questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of an iron deficiency anemia. In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

Prolonged NSAID use is a common cause of upper GI Bleed as seen in this patient where it presents as anemia and blood loss. Chronic GI blood loss is one of the most common causes of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by _________
questions.solution:
Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning. Carbolic acid is a corrosive acid, however, it hardens the GI mucosa producing a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. This allows for gastric lavage.

Contraindications of Gastric lavage:

  • Corrosives poisoning (except carbolic acid)
  • Convulsants/CNS stimulants
  • Comatose patients
  • Volatile poison
  • Upper GI pathology (eg. esophageal varices)
  • Hypothermic patient
  • Severe heart disease
  • Advanced pregnancy

Sulphuric acid and kerosene are corrosives and strychnine is a convulsant. Hence gastric lavage is not done in these poisonings.

 

 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of corrosives

Corrosive Mechanism of Action Type of necrosis
Strong acids Hydrogen ions penetrate tisues and lead to cell death and eschar formation. This prevents further hydrogen ion penetration and protects against deeper injury. Coagulation necrosis
Strong alkalis Hydroxide ion easily penetrates tissues, leading to dissolution of cell membranes. Alkali are associated with deep tissue injury. Liquefaction necrosis
Hydrofluoric acid Hydrogen ions cause direct cellular damage, as with other acids. Also, fluoride ions scavenge intracellular cations, such as calcium and magnesium and inhibit Na/K ATPase, disrupting cell membranes. This leads to hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia  and liquefaction necrosis Liquefaction necrosis
Carbolic acid Carbolic acid also acts by the same mechanism as other strong acids, but it also hardens the GI mucosa, producing a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. This allows for gastric lavage. Coagulation necrosis 
Oxalic acid Acts by the same mechanism as other strong acids, but also scavenges calcium ions, leading to hypocalcemia and Calcium oxalate renal stones.  Coagulation necrosis

Shiga toxin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Its site of action is in the endothelial cells of small blood vessels of GIT.

questions.text: In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed?
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1 , couple protection rate ( CPR ) should exceed 60%

Pearl Index:

  • The pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).
  • Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher order births.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the area marked on the visceral surface of the spleen?
questions.solution: The area marked on the visceral surface of the spleen is related to the left kidney.

questions.text: What is the definition of the net reproduction rate?

choices.text: No. of children that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of girls  that would be born to married women assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of female children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate
No. of children a new born girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age specific fertility and mortality rate

questions.solution:
Net reproduction rate (NRR) is defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate.

India is aiming for an NRR of 1 as it is equivalent to the two-child norm.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent a nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient?
questions.solution:
Acetaminophen can be given as an analgesic for the patient as it is the least nephrotoxic among the given options.

Analgesia in CKD patients:

Acetaminophen is considered a safer non-narcotic analgesic in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients. For more severe pains opioid analgesics like tramadol or fentanyl are used. 

Even though acetaminophen is considered safe, with chronic high dosage it can also become nephrotoxic.

NSAIDs like naproxen, indomethacin, diclofenac, etc are not used in CKD patients because of their direct nephrotoxic effects. In healthy normal individuals, NSAIDs have little effect on renal function and blood pressure. But in conditions where the regulatory systems are impaired as hypovolemia, congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, or other conditions where the renin-angiotensin system is activated, renal function by the formation of prostaglandins are very important.

NSAIDs cause impairment of prostaglandin-induced inhibition of chlorine reabsorption and antidiuretic hormone action. This will cause salt and water retention. It also inhibits COX-2 derived prostaglandins which regulate the renal medullary blood flow and would lead to a rise in blood pressure, increased cardiovascular thrombotic events, and cardiac failure. It can also cause electrolyte abnormalities like hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutter and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which breaks down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of Foot.

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics.

Phaeohyphomycosis : it is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions maybe plaques which are verrucous, hypertkeratotis or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other demetacious fungi.

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change:
questions.solution:
The image shows suggillation.

Livor mortis/postmortem hypostasis/ postmortem staining/ postmortem lividity/ suggillation refers to bluish-purple or purplish-red discolouration (due to deoxyhaemoglobin) of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependent parts of the body as a result of capillary-venous distention.

The timeline for the development of postmortem staining:

  • Mottled patches: 1-3 hours following the death.
  • Uniform area of staining: 3-6 hours following the death.
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis: 6-12 hours following the death. It occurs earlier in summer and is delayed in asphyxial deaths and intracranial lesions.  
    It persists until putrefaction sets in.

Medicolegal importance: Postmortem staining and its fixation can be helpful in ascertaining the time since death. It can also be used to estimate the body's position at the time of death and if the body has been relocated since. 

Other options:

Option A: Tattooing is the process of inserting ink into the dermal layer of the skin to create permanent designs. It involves using a needle to puncture the skin and deposit ink, resulting in a permanent mark or image on the body.

Option C: Putrefaction is the process of decomposition of organic matter, typically resulting from bacterial activity. It leads to the breakdown of tissues, producing foul odours and the release of gases.

Option D: Decomposition is the natural breakdown of organic matter into simpler substances, often facilitated by microorganisms. It involves stages such as autolysis, putrefaction, and mineralization, contributing to nutrient recycling in ecosystems.

questions.text: Among the following, what is the function of the marked muscles?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is the lateral pterygoid muscle and its function is the depression of the mandible (opening of the mouth)

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  1. Opening of the jaw (depression): Lateral pterygoid has a specialized role in mandibular opening mediated by its horizontal fibres. When left and right lateral pterygoid muscles contract together, the mandibular condyle is pulled forwards and slightly downwards. This protrusive movement alone has little or no function except in assisting the opening the jaw (Gray's Anatomy 41st edition).
  2. Side-to-side movement: When the lateral pterygoid contracts unilaterally along with the adjacent medial pterygoid the jaw is pulled medially. This is used for grinding food between teeth of the same side. This action is mediated by the inferior head of lateral pterygoid.

Note:

  • Among the four mastication muscles (temporalis, masseter, medial pterygoid, lateral pterygoid), the lateral pterygoid is the only muscle that helps in depression/opening of the jaw. 
  • The main jaw opener muscles are digastric and geniohyoid

questions.text: Plateau of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve signifies ______

choices.text: No Hb is available to bind
No oxygen is available for binding

questions.solution:
• The plateau of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) corresponds to almost 100% saturation of hemoglobin, with all heme groups bound to O2, and affinity for O2 at its highest value due to positive cooperativity.
  • OHDC is sigmoid with the upper end, between a blood Po2 of 60 mm Hg-100 mmHg, the curve flattens off, or plateaus. (refer figure).
  • The plateau portion of the curve is in the blood Po2 range at the pulmonary capillaries where O2 is being loaded onto Hb. (where Po2 and affinity are highest).
  • The steep portion of the curve between 0 and 60 mm Hg is in the blood Po2 range at the systemic capillaries, where O2 is unloaded from Hb. (where Po2 and affinity are lower).

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the WHO definition of health?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO, health is “a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity”.

In recent years, the definition has been modified to also include the ability to lead a “socially and economically productive life.”

questions.text: Quarantine was first applied for ------.
questions.solution:
• In the 14th century, quarantine was used for plague.
  • Plague is also called ‘black death’.

questions.text: What does the neurohypophysis release?
questions.solution:
The posterior pituitary or neurohypophysis releases oxytocin and anti-diuretic hormone (ADH or vasopressin) 

Note: ADH and oxytocin are synthesised by the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus and are released from the posterior pituitary.

questions.text: Which is the commonly noted vitamin deficiency In drought-affected areas?
questions.solution: The vitamin most commonly deficient in areas of famines and droughts is vitamin A; deficiency of this vitamin leads to xerophthalmia and blindness.

questions.text: A surgeon performing a radical neck dissection wants to start at the anterior triangle. Which of the following areas will she not dissect?
questions.solution:
The subclavian triangle is a posterior triangle of the neck.

Anterior triangle consists of:

  • Submental triangle
  • Digastric triangle
  • Muscular triangle
  • Carotid triangle

Posterior triangles in the neck are occipital and subclavian triangles.

questions.text: Most common pneumoconiosis in the world is _________.
questions.solution:
Silicosis is the most common pnemoconiosis in the world.

Silicosis is caused by inhalation of crystalline silica (e.g., quartz). Individuals involved with the concrete work, sandblasting, stone carvers, and jewelers using chalk molds are at high risk.

Pneumoconioses encompass a group of chronic fibrosing diseases of the lung resulting from exposure to organic and inorganic particulates, most commonly mineral dust.

questions.text: An accredited social health activist is offering services under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan in her village. All of the following services will be provided by her except:

choices.text: Information, education, communication and public awareness

questions.solution:
Water pollution is not managed under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan.

The Swachh Bharat Abhiyan was launched in 2014 with an aim to eradicate open-air defecation by the year 2019 through the construction of 12 million toilets. The two sub-missions of Swachh Bharat Abhiyan are Swachh Bharat Mission Gramin (SBM-G) and Swachh Bharat Mission Urban (SBM-U).

  • Components of this mission include:
    • Household toilets including improving unsanitary latrines
    • Community toilets
    • Public toilets
    • Solid waste management
    • Information, education, communication, and public awareness
    • Capacity building and administrative & office expenses

An Accredited Social Health Activist(ASHA), is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with formal education of up to eighth grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: The likely diagnosis based on the serum electrophoresis image is:
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates a sharp peak ("church spire” or M band) in the gamma globulin region. This is characteristically seen in a patient with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma involves a malignant proliferation of plasma cells, resulting in excessive production of abnormal immunoglobulins, causing a spike called the M band.

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased (M BAND)
Liver cirrhosis Reduced albumin and compensatory increase in globulin
Primary immune deficiency Gamma globulin reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

questions.text: The most undesirable metal in drinking water is ______
questions.solution:
The most undesirable metal in drinking water is lead.

World Water Day (22nd March of every year) is an annual UN observance day that highlights the importance of freshwater. The theme for World Water Day 2019 is 'Leaving no one behind'. 

Marginalized groups – women, children, refugees, indigenous peoples, disabled people and many others – are often overlooked, and sometimes face discrimination, as they try to access and manage the safe water they need. This World Water Day is about tackling the water crisis by addressing the reasons why so many people are being left behind.

Note: The theme for world water day 2020 is "Water and climate change".

questions.text: A sexually active woman who was using barrier contraceptives is planning on switching to DMPA injectables. Which of the following is the correct dosage of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
The dosage for injectable depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is 150 mg every 3 months.

The mechanism of contraception are

  • Mainly by preventing ovulation
  • Bringing changes in the cervical mucus
  • Making the endometrium hostile

An important advantage is that it does not affect lactation. Therefore it is an important contraceptive  during the postpartum period to space pregnancies. The side-effects of DMPA include weight gain, irregular menstrual bleeding and prolonged infertility after its use.

Antara (Injectable contraceptive DMPA) and Chhaya (non harmonal oral contraceptive Centchroman) were recently launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas.

questions.text: Which of the following is not directly involved in graft rejection?
questions.solution:
Macrophages present foreign graft antigens to the T-cells but are not directly involved in graft rejection.

Graft rejection is both humoral and cell-mediated in nature. It is a process in which T-cells and antibodies produced against graft antigens react against tissue grafts and destroy it.

The major antigenic differences that result in the rejection of transplants are differences in HLA alleles. The recipient T-cells are involved in the recognition of the donor MHC molecules and mount an immune response. Depending on the antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that are involved in T-cell activation, there are 2 pathways:

  • Direct pathway of allorecognition - MHC antigens are presented by the APCs in the graft
  • Indirect pathway of allorecognition - MHC antigens are presented by the recipient’s own APCs (e.g., macrophages)

The early activation of NK cells kill allogeneic target cells directly or via antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and release various chemokines and immunomodulatory cytokines.

questions.text: A 5-year- old child presents with scanty, foul smelling ear discharge. On examination, perforation was seen in pars flaccida of tympanic membrane. Management includes  _____
questions.solution: Scanty, purulent, foul smelling is seen in Atticoantral type of CSOM. Here, the mainstay of treatment is surgery, i.e., Mastoid exploration.

questions.text: The PARK procedure is used in the correction of which of the following?
questions.solution:
PARK stands for photo-astigmatic refractive keratotomy, a technique that is used for correcting astigmatism.

Surgical procedures used for correction of astigmatism are as follows:

  • Astigmatic Keratotomy
  • PARK
  • LASIK
  • SMILE
